com.siperian.sif.message.mrm

Class ExecuteBatchGroupRequest

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.siperian.sif.message.SiperianRequest
      • com.siperian.sif.message.mrm.ExecuteBatchGroupRequest
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable

    public class ExecuteBatchGroupRequest
extends SiperianRequest
    A BatchGroup is a set of batch jobs executed together, some sequentially and some in parallel according to the configuration. When one job has an error, the group will stop; that is, no more jobs will be started, but running jobs will run to completion. There are three (3) related services in this API:

    • ResetBatchGroup
    • ExecuteBatchGroup
    • GetBatchGroupStatus

    Note: In addition to these Java APIs and the SOAP and HTTP XML protocols always available for SIF, these three (3) Batch Group APIs also have database stored procedures available:

    • cmxbg.execute_batchgroup
    • cmxbg.reset_batchgroup
    • cmxbg.get_batchgroup_status

    For more information, see Chapter 18, "Writing Custom Scripts to Execute Batch Jobs", in the Siperian Hub Administrator Guide.

    A group that stopped for an error may be resumed or restarted.

    Restart will ignore previous executions, and run jobs from the beginning. For a script using this API, if resume is never wanted use setResume(boolean)=false.

    Resume will skip all successful jobs of the previous execution, running the failed job and non-started jobs. For a script using this API, where the script can resume itself (starting after succesful steps), it should be written to call MRM in 2 steps:

    1. Call ResetBatchGroupRequest.
    2. Call ExecuteBatchGroupRequest with setResume(boolean)=true.

    That way, a resume of the script would not repeat the call to ResetBatchGroupRequest, however, when the script is run the next day, both MRM calls would be made so the group would be executed from the beginning.

    Required Parameter:

    • setBatchGroupUid(String) - Identify batch group. May be set by constructor.

    Optional Parameter:

    • setResume(boolean) - Resume last failed execution or restart a new one. Default is true.

    Usage Example:

    A batch group can be resumed after an error. However, an automated script may need its own ability to resume. The Java code below illustrates how to do this involving execution of a batch group. 

    
 // Example for a script that runs periodically and can resume itself,
 // maybe as part of a larger process including ETL.
 
 // The RESUME POINTs below are for example. To implement this,
 // you would need to store the completed point somewhere (disk)
 // and if the script is started to resume,
 // only execute points that were not completed.
 
 // RESUME POINT 1:
 // pre-Siperian ETL
 
 // RESUME POINT 2:
 // load into Siperian Landing tables
    
 
 // RESUME POINT 3:
 // Reset the batch group so it will start new
 
 String myBatchGroupUid = SiperianObjectType.BATCH_GROUP.makeUid("MyBatchGroup");
 
 ResetBatchGroupResponse reset = (ResetBatchGroupResponse) sipClient.process( new ResetBatchGroupRequest(myBatchGroupUid) );
 if (reset. getRowidBatchGroupLog() != null) {
   System.out.println("Reset MRM batch group " + myBatchGroupUid
     + ": log id= " + reset. getRowidBatchGroupLog() );
 }
 
 // RESUME POINT 4:
 // If exec failed, and now resuming at POINT-4,
 // then POINT-3 will not be called, so the batch group itself will resume.
 
 System.out.println("Starting MRM batch group, " + myBatchGroupUid);
 // note, this is synchronous, so may take hours
 ExecuteBatchGroupResponse executed = (ExecuteBatchGroupResponse) sipClient.process( new ExecuteBatchGroupRequest(myBatchGroupUid, true) );
 System.out.println("Finished MRM batch group, " + myBatchGroupUid ": log id= " + executed. getRowidBatchGroupLog() );
 
 // RESUME POINT 5:
 // post-Siperian ETL and other processes

    If the group is executed asynchronously, the status can be found using the normal mechanism of a JMS reply queue (see AsynchronousOptions). Alternatively, the status can be polled for using GetBatchGroupStatusRequest. 

     // Example that runs a batch group async
 
 String myBatchGroupUid = SiperianObjectType.BATCH_GROUP.makeUid("MyBatchGroup");
 
 System.out.println("Starting MRM batch group, " + myBatchGroupUid);
 // in this example, don't resume, always reset
 ExecuteBatchGroupRequest exec = new ExecuteBatchGroupRequest(myBatchGroupUid, false);
 exec. setAsynchronousOptions( new AsynchronousOptions(true) );
 ExecuteBatchGroupResponse executed = (ExecuteBatchGroupResponse) sipClient.process(executed);
 System.out.println("Started MRM batch group, " + myBatchGroupUid + ": log id= " + executed. getRowidBatchGroupLog() );
 
 // Wait some time, or loop and wait
 
 GetBatchGroupStatusRequest statReq = new GetBatchGroupStatusRequest();
 statReq.setRowidBatchGroupLog(executed. getRowidBatchGroupLog());
 GetBatchGroupStatusResponse stat = (GetBatchGroupStatusResponse) sipClient.process(statReq);
 if (stat.getRunStatus() == GetBatchGroupStatusResponse. STATUS_RUNNING) {
   System.out.println("Running MRM batch group, " + myBatchGroupUid
     + ": log id= " + stat. getRowidBatchGroupLog()
     + ", started " + stat.getStartRunDate());
 } else {
   System.out.println("Finished MRM batch group, " + myBatchGroupUid
     + ": log id= " + stat. getRowidBatchGroupLog()
     + ", " + stat. getRunStatus() + ", " + stat.getMessage());
   // if looping, exit loop here
 }

    SiperianClient.process( ExecuteBatchGroupRequest ) will respond with a ExecuteBatchGroupResponse.

    See Also:
    ExecuteBatchGroupResponse, ResetBatchGroupRequest, ResetBatchGroupResponse, GetBatchGroupStatusRequest, GetBatchGroupStatusResponse, Serialized Form

    API Pair: ExecuteBatchGroupResponse

    API Group: Batch Groups

      • getTransactionAttributeType

        public TransactionAttributeType getTransactionAttributeType()
        Transaction for this request is NOT_SUPPORTED. This request can not participate in an outside transaction because each job in a group may have its own transaction.
        Overrides:
        getTransactionAttributeType in class SiperianRequest
        Returns:
        Never null, and constant for each request subclass.
